verse: He made a bronze altar ·thirty feet [twenty cubits] long, ·thirty feet [twenty cubits] wide, and ·fifteen feet [ten cubits] tall.

Then he made from ·bronze [cast metal] a large round ·bowl [basin], which was called the Sea [symbol of chaos subdued; 1 Kin. 7:23]. It was ·forty-five feet [thirty cubits] ·around [in circumference], ·fifteen feet [ten cubits] ·across [from rim to rim], and ·seven and one-half feet [five cubits] ·deep [high].

There were ·carvings [figures; images] of ·bulls [oxen] under the rim of the bowl—ten ·bulls [oxen] every ·eighteen inches [cubit]. They were in two rows and were ·made [cast] in one piece with the bowl.

The bowl rested on the backs of twelve bronze ·bulls [oxen] ·that faced outward from the center of the bowl [all their hindquarters were toward the inside]. Three ·bulls [oxen] faced north, three faced west, three faced south, and three faced east.

The sides of the bowl were ·four inches [four fingers; a handbreadth] thick, and it held ·about seventeen thousand five hundred gallons [three thousand baths]. The rim of the bowl was like the rim of a cup ·or like [and resembled] a lily blossom.

He made ten ·smaller bowls [basins] and put five on the ·south [right] side and five on the ·north [left]. They were for ·washing [rinsing] the ·animals [or utensils; things] for the burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17], but the ·large bowl [Sea; v. 2] was for the priests to wash in.
He ·made [cast] ten lampstands of gold, ·following the plans [according to the specifications]. He put them in the Temple, five on the ·south [right] side and five on the ·north [left].
He made ten tables and put them in the Temple, five on the ·south [right] side and five on the ·north [left]. And he used gold to ·make [mold] a hundred other ·bowls [basins].
He also made the priests’ courtyard and the large courtyard. He made the doors that opened to the courtyard and ·covered [overlaid] them with bronze.
Then he put the large ·bowl [basin; the Sea] on the right side toward the southeast corner.
Huram also made ·bowls [pots; pails; washbasins], shovels, and ·small [or sprinkling] bowls. So he finished his work for King Solomon on the ·Temple [house] of God:
The king had these things ·poured [cast] into clay molds that were made in the plain of the Jordan River between Succoth and Zarethan.
Solomon had so many things made that the total weight of all the bronze ·was never known [could not be/was not calculated].
Solomon also made all the ·things [furnishings] for God’s ·Temple [house]: the golden altar; tables which held the bread ·that shows God’s people are in his presence [of Presence; Ex. 25:23–30];
the lampstands and their lamps of ·pure [solid] gold, to burn in front of the ·Most Holy Place [inner sanctuary] as ·planned [prescribed; specified];
the flowers, lamps, and tongs of pure gold;

the pure gold ·wick trimmers [lamp snuffers], small bowls, pans, and dishes ·used to carry coals [and incense burners/censers], the gold doors for the ·Temple [house], and the inside doors of the ·Most Holy Place [Holy of Holies] and of the ·main room [main hall; nave].
